review.title: A Game-Theoretic Approach to Word Sense Disambiguation
review.abstract: This paper presents a new model for word sense disambiguation formulated in terms of evolutionary game theory, where each word to be disambiguated is represented as a node on a graph whose edges represent word relations and senses are represented as classes. The words simultaneously update their class membership preferences according to the senses that neighboring words are likely to choose. We use distributional information to weigh the influence that each word has on the decisions of the others and semantic similarity information to measure the strength of compatibility among the choices. With this information we can formulate the word sense disambiguation problem as a constraint satisfaction problem and solve it using tools derived from game theory, maintaining the textual coherence. The model is based on two ideas: similar words should be assigned to similar classes and the meaning of a word does not depend on all the words in a text but just on some of them. The paper provides an in-depth motivation of the idea of modeling the word sense disambiguation problem in terms of game theory, which is illustrated by an example. The conclusion presents an extensive analysis on the combination of similarity measures to use in the framework and a comparison with state-of-the-art systems. The results show that our model outperforms state-of-the-art algorithms and can be applied to different tasks and in different scenarios.

sections.heading: 3. Word Sense Disambiguation as a Consistent Labeling Problem
sections.text: WSD can be interpreted as a meaning-marking task (Navigli 2009), which consists in assigning a meaning-marking task to a target word. As a marking problem, we need an algorithm that fulfils this task in a consistent way, taking into account the context in which the target word occurs. Following this observation, we can formulate the WSD task as a problem of satisfaction limitation (Tsang 1995), in which the marking process must fulfil some constraints in order to be consistent. This approach gives us the opportunity not only to exploit the contextual information of a word, but also to find the most appropriate meaning association for the target word and the words in its context. This is the most important contribution of our work that distinguishes it from existing WSD algorithms. In fact, in some cases we only use contextual information without imposing consistencies that can lead to inconsistencies in the assignment of related words.

sections.heading: 4. Game Theory
sections.text: In this section, we briefly present the basic concepts of classical game theory and evolutionary game theory that we have used in our framework; for a more detailed analysis of these topics, please refer to the reader (Weibull 1997; Leyton-Brown and Shoham 2008; Sandholm 2010).

sections.heading: 4.1 Classical Game Theory
sections.text: Game theory provides predictive power in interactive decision-making situations. It was introduced by Neumann and Morgenstern (1944) to develop a mathematical framework capable of modelling the fundamentals of decision-making in interactive situations. In its normal form, it represents strategies we use in this article. It consists of a finite group of players I = {1,.., n}, a set of pure strategies for each player Si = {s1,..., sm}, and a utility function ui: S1 × Sn → R, which associates strategies to payouts. Any player can adopt a strategy to play a game, and the utility function depends on the combination of strategies played simultaneously by players who are not only involved in the strategy of a single player. An important assumption in game theory is that players are rational and try to maximize the value of the strategy.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions
sections.text: In this article we have introduced a new method for WSD based on game theory. We have given a comprehensive introduction to the WSD task and explained the motivations behind the choice to model the WSD problem as a satisfaction problem. We have conducted an extensive series of experiments to find the similarity measures that work better within our framework. We have also evaluated our system with two different implementations and compared our results with the most advanced systems. Our method can be considered a continuation of the knowledge based on approaches. We have combined and compared the methodology of these three approaches. This model is used to perform a consistent labeling of the senses.
